admreg: East Asia and Pacific,East Asia and Pacific

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Manila Power
            Distribution Project in Philippines are as follows: overall
            outcome of the project was rated satisfactory, and the
            performance of the Bank and Borrower were also rated
            satisfactory. Some of the lessons learned from the project
            are: 1) in designing future Bank projects with on-lending to
            private borrowers, the Bank may need to study the private
            sector's decision making process towards official
            development finance. A proper understanding of the private
            sector to find out the level of commitment and how it is
            expressed may be vital; and 2) the critical issue facing the
            distribution utilities is to become sufficiently
            credit-worthy to secure loans and equity capital on their
            own in the capital market. As in the case of Manila Electric
            Company (MERALCO), available official development finance
            can help them begin that process. The problem is one of
            devising legally appropriate transitional financing
            mechanism for channeling the development finance. To the
            extent that some of the remaining 145 distribution companies
            in the Philippines, representing some 40 percent of the
            distribution capacity, become credible borrowers through a
            consolidation program, Development Bank of the Philippine
            (DBP) could serve as a channel for development finance to
            recast their operations and finances to be able to meet
            their future development finance from the market.
